sections.title: The Golden Mean
sections.content: Virtue, then, is a state of character concerned with choice, lying in a mean, i.e. the mean relative to us, this being determined by a rational principle, and by that principle by which the man of practical wisdom would determine it. Now it is a mean between two vices, that which depends on excess and that which depends on defect; and again it is a mean because the vices respectively fall short of or exceed what is right in both passions and actions, while virtue both finds and chooses that which is intermediate. Hence also it is no easy task to be good. For in everything it is no easy task to find the middle, e.g. to find the middle of a circle is not for everyone but for him who knows; so, too, any one can get angry—that is easy—or give or spend money; but to do this to the right person, to the right extent, at the right time, with the right motive, and in the right way, that is not for everyone, nor is it easy; wherefore goodness is both rare and laudable and noble.

sections.title: Eudaimonia
sections.content: If, then, there is some end of the things we do, which we desire for its own sake (everything else being desired for the sake of this), and if we do not choose everything for the sake of something else (for at that rate the process would go on to infinity, so that our desire would be empty and vain), clearly this must be the good and the chief good. Will not the knowledge of it, then, have a great influence on life? Shall we not, like archers who have a mark to aim at, be more likely to hit upon what is right? And if so, we must try, in outline at least, to determine what it is, and of which of the sciences or capacities it is the object. It would seem to belong to the most authoritative art and that which is most truly the master art. And politics appears to be of this nature; for it is this that ordains which of the sciences should be studied in a state, and which each class of citizens should learn and up to what point; indeed, we see even the most highly esteemed of capacities to fall under this, e.g. strategy, economics, rhetoric; now, since politics uses the rest of the sciences, and since, again, it legislates as to what we are to do and what we are to abstain from, the end of this science must include those of the others, so that this end must be the good for man.

sections.title: Practical Wisdom
sections.content: We think that practical wisdom is concerned with the things human and things about which it is possible to deliberate; for we say that it is above all the work of the man of practical wisdom to deliberate well, and no one deliberates about things that cannot be otherwise, nor about things that are not directed to some end and that is a good attainable by action. But the man who is good at deliberating in general is the one who is capable of aiming in accordance with calculation at the best for man of things attainable by action. Nor is practical wisdom concerned with universals only—it must also recognize the particulars; for it is concerned with action and action is concerned with particulars. Hence some who do not know, and especially those who have experience, are more practical than others who know. For if a man knew that light meats are digestible and wholesome, but did not know which sorts of meat are light, he would not produce health; but the man who knows that chicken is wholesome is more likely to produce health.

sections.title: Friendship
sections.content: Now those who wish for the good of their friends for the friends' sake are friends most of all; for they have this attitude by reference to the friends themselves, not as a result of something else. Hence their friendship lasts as long as they are good; and goodness is an enduring thing. And each is good both absolutely and for his friend, since the good are both absolutely good and useful to each other. Similarly they are pleasant; for the good are both absolutely pleasant and pleasant to each other, since each takes pleasure in his own actions and actions like his own, and the actions of the good are the same or similar. Such friendship is, as might be expected, permanent, since it possesses all the qualities that friends should have. For all friendship aims at goodness and at pleasure, and these are found most in this kind, since it possesses the greatest goodness and the most lasting pleasure. And it is likely to be felt towards few people; for such men are rare.

sections.title: Contemplation
sections.content: If happiness is activity in accordance with virtue, it is reasonable that it should be in accordance with the highest virtue; and this will be that of the best thing in us. Whether it be intellect or something else that is this element which is thought to be our natural ruler and guide and to take thought of things noble and divine, whether it be itself also divine or only the most divine element in us, the activity of this in accordance with its proper virtue will be perfect happiness. That this activity is contemplative we have already said. Now this would seem to be in agreement both with what we said before and with the truth. For this activity is the highest (since the intellect is the highest thing in us, and the objects of intellect are the highest things that can be known); and also it is the most continuous, since we can contemplate truth more continuously than we can do anything else. And we think that happiness has pleasure mingled with it, but the activity of philosophic wisdom is admittedly the pleasantest of virtuous activities; at any rate the pursuit of it is thought to offer pleasures wonderful for their purity and their enduringness, and it is reasonable to suppose that those who know will pass their time more pleasantly than those who inquire.

sections.title: Control and Choice
sections.content: Some things are up to us, and some things are not up to us. Our opinions are up to us, and our impulses, desires, aversions—in short, whatever is our own doing. Our bodies are not up to us, nor are our possessions, our reputations, or our public offices, or, in short, whatever is not our own doing. The things that are up to us are by nature free, not subject to hindrance or restraint; but the things that are not up to us are weak, slavish, subject to hindrance, and not our own. Remember, then, that if you think the things that are by nature slavish are free, and the things that are not your own are your own, you will be hindered, you will lament, you will be disturbed, you will blame both gods and men.

sections.title: Desire and Aversion
sections.content: Don't demand that things happen as you wish, but wish that they happen as they do happen, and you will go on well. Illness is a hindrance to the body, but not to the will, unless the will consents. Lameness is a hindrance to the leg, but not to the will. Say this to yourself at each event that occurs: 'This is what I demanded.' For if you are willing to accept things as they are, you will be happy; but if you are not willing, you will be unhappy and wretched. This is the nature of the good: it is always available to us, if we are willing to see it. The good is not in external things, but in the use we make of them.

sections.title: Action and Character
sections.content: It is not death or pain that is to be feared, but the fear of death or pain. Welcome death, therefore, and you will be free from the fear of it. Welcome pain, and you will be free from the fear of it. The wise person does not sit and whine, nor does he run away from difficulties. He faces them squarely and overcomes them. It is not the event that matters, but our response to it. We cannot control what happens to us, but we can control how we respond. Character is not made in a crisis—it is only exhibited. True character is revealed in the choices we make when no one is watching.

sections.title: Relationships and Society
sections.content: If you wish to be a friend to anyone, be a friend to him in the way that is right for you. But don't expect him to be a friend in the way that is right for you. If he does, well and good; if not, he is not your friend. Don't be surprised if you find that some people are ungrateful, or selfish, or dishonest. That is their nature. You cannot change their nature, but you can change your response to it. Treat everyone with kindness, but don't expect anything in return. Your duty is to be virtuous, not to make others virtuous. The good person helps others not because he expects reward, but because it is the right thing to do.

sections.title: Practice and Habit
sections.content: Practice, therefore, from the start to say to every harsh appearance: 'You are an appearance, and not at all the thing you appear to be.' Then examine it by the rules you have, first and chiefly by this: whether it concerns the things that are up to us or the things that are not up to us. And if it concerns anything not up to us, be ready to say: 'It is nothing to me.' Remember that the door is open. Don't be more cowardly than children, but just as they say when they don't like the game, 'I won't play anymore,' so you too, when things seem that way to you, say 'I won't play anymore' and depart. But if you stay, don't complain.

sections.title: Bad Faith
sections.content: Bad faith is a lie to oneself. The one who practices bad faith is hiding a displeasing truth or presenting as truth a pleasing untruth. Bad faith then has in appearance the structure of falsehood. Only what changes is the intention. In the case of bad faith, the intention is to flee from oneself, to flee from what one is in order to establish oneself as what one is not. But this flight from oneself is not a flight toward something else; it is a flight from oneself toward oneself.

sections.title: Freedom
sections.content: Man is condemned to be free; because once thrown into the world, he is responsible for everything he does. It is up to you to give [life] a meaning. Man is nothing else but that which he makes of himself. That is the first principle of existentialism. And this is what people call its 'subjectivity,' using the word as a reproach against us. But what do we mean to say by this, but that man is of a greater dignity than a stone or a table? For we mean to say that man primarily exists - that man is, before he is anything else, something which propels itself towards a future and is aware that it is doing so.

sections.title: Chapter 8
sections.content: The supreme good is like water, which nourishes all things without trying to. It is content with the low places that people disdain. Thus it is like the Tao. In dwelling, live close to the ground. In thinking, keep to the simple. In conflict, be fair and generous. In governing, don't try to control. In work, do what you enjoy. In family life, be completely present. When you are content to be simply yourself and don't compare or compete, everybody will respect you.

sections.title: Chapter 15
sections.content: The ancient masters were profound and subtle. Their wisdom was unfathomable. There is no way to describe it; all we can describe is their appearance. They were careful as someone crossing an iced-over stream. Alert as a warrior in enemy territory. Courteous as a guest. Fluid as melting ice. Shapeable as a block of wood. Receptive as a valley. Clear as a glass of water. Do you have the patience to wait till your mud settles and the water is clear? Can you remain unmoving till the right action arises by itself?

sections.title: Book I: Gratitude and Role Models
sections.content: From my grandfather Verus I learned good morals and the government of my temper. From the reputation and remembrance of my father, modesty and a manly character. From my mother, piety and beneficence, and abstinence, not only from evil deeds, but even from evil thoughts; and further, simplicity in my way of living, far removed from the habits of the rich. From my great-grandfather, not to have frequented public schools, and to have had good teachers at home, and to know that on such things a man should spend liberally.

sections.title: Book I: Legacy and Duty
sections.content: From Rusticus I received the impression that my character required improvement and discipline; and from him I learned not to be led astray to sophistic emulation, nor to writing on speculative matters, nor to delivering little hortatory orations, nor to showing myself off as a man of letters or a philanthropist or a busybody. I learned to abstain from rhetoric, poetry, and fine writing; and not to walk about in the house in my outdoor dress, nor to do other things of the kind; nor to write letters in a style that seeks to please, like the letters of Rusticus.

sections.title: Book II: Morning Practice
sections.content: Begin the morning by saying to thyself, I shall meet with the busybody, the ungrateful, arrogant, deceitful, envious, unsocial. All these things happen to them by reason of their ignorance of what is good and evil. But I who have seen the nature of the good that it is beautiful, and of the bad that it is ugly, and the nature of him who does wrong, that it is akin to me, not only of the same blood or seed, but that it participates in the same intelligence and the same portion of the divinity, I can neither be injured by any of them, for no one can fix on me what is ugly, nor can I be angry with my kinsman, nor hate him.

sections.title: Book II: The Soul's Nature
sections.content: Everything that happens is either endurable or not. If it is endurable, then endure it. Stop complaining. If it is unendurable, then stop complaining. Your destruction will mean its end as well. But remember, you can endure anything your mind can make endurable, by treating it as in your interest to do so. In your interest, or in your nature. If it is in your interest to treat something as easy, treat it as easy. If as profitable, treat it as profitable. If as duty, treat it as duty. And if you complain about a thing, you add to its harm.

sections.title: Book III: Death and Perspective
sections.content: Alexander the Great and his mule driver both died and the same thing happened to both. They were absorbed alike into the generative principle of the universe. Or they were alike distributed into atoms. Consider how many times a day your thoughts dwell on death, and yet you do not reflect that when you have died, you will no longer be troubled by any such thoughts. Is not this strange? Or do you not think it strange that a man should live as if he were never going to die, and yet complain when death comes slowly?

sections.title: Book III: Inner Citadel
sections.content: The mind is its own place, and in itself can make a heaven of hell, a hell of heaven. If you have a wound, you can retreat to your own mind and be at peace. If you are troubled, you can find refuge in your ruling faculty. For the mind, when it is not itself disturbed, is not disturbed by anything external. What then can disturb the mind? The answer is: opinions about things. Take away these opinions, and peace remains. And who can take away opinions? Only the mind itself, by refusing to accept them.

sections.title: Book IV: Inner Retreat
sections.content: The happiness of your life depends upon the quality of your thoughts. Therefore, guard accordingly, and take care that you entertain no notions unsuitable to virtue and reasonable nature. Men seek retreats for themselves, houses in the country, sea-shores, and mountains; and thou too art wont to desire such things very much. But this is altogether a mark of the most common sort of men, for it is in thy power whenever thou shalt choose to retire into thyself. For nowhere either with more quiet or more freedom from trouble does a man retire than into his own soul.

sections.title: Book IV: Nature's Design
sections.content: Everything is interwoven, and the web is holy; there is probably not one thread that is isolated or alone. For all things are interdependent, and they combine to form the same universe. For there is one universe made up of all things, and one god who pervades all things, and one substance, and one law, one common reason in all intelligent animals, and one truth. If this is so, then there is also one perfection for all who are of the same stock and participate in the same reason.

sections.title: Book V: Providence and Acceptance
sections.content: Whatever happens to you has been waiting to happen since the beginning of time. The twining strands of fate weave both good and ill into the same cloth. The one is inseparable from the other. If you accept this, you will accept whatever happens with equanimity. For what is the difference between accepting it now or later? The events are the same. Only your attitude toward them changes. Accept what nature sends you. In the long run, it makes no difference whether you accept it or not. But in the short run, acceptance brings peace.

sections.title: Book V: The Present Moment
sections.content: Do not disturb thyself by thinking of the whole of thy life. Let not thy thoughts at once embrace all the various troubles that thou mayest expect to befall thee: but on every occasion ask thyself, What is there in this that is intolerable and past bearing? For thou wilt be ashamed to confess. In the next place, remember that neither the future nor the past pains thee, but only the present. But this is reduced to a very little, if thou only circumscribest it, and chidest thy mind, if it is unable to hold out against even this.

sections.title: Book VI: Self-Knowledge
sections.content: The best way of avenging thyself is not to become like the wrong doer. The best way of avenging thyself is to become unlike him. The best way of avenging thyself is to forgive him. The best way of avenging thyself is to love him. For hatred never ceases by hatred, but by love alone is healed. This is an ancient and eternal law. The happiness of thy life depends upon the quality of thy thoughts: therefore, guard accordingly, and take care that thou entertain no notions unsuitable to virtue and reasonable nature.

sections.title: Book VI: True Self
sections.content: Look within. Within is the fountain of good, and it will ever bubble up, if thou wilt ever dig. The soul must be made impervious to all external influences. It must be like a fortress, whose garrison is reason. For the soul that is disciplined and purified is a fortress that cannot be taken. The soul that is in harmony with reason is a fortress that cannot be shaken. The soul that is in harmony with nature is a fortress that cannot be conquered.

sections.title: Book VII: Impermanence
sections.content: How ridiculous and how strange to be surprised at anything which happens in life! If a potter makes a vessel and it breaks in the kiln or oven, is he surprised? No. But if a man breaks, we say, 'Alas, what has happened?' Learn then not to be surprised at the breakage of a vessel, nor at the death of a man. For as the vessel is broken, so must a man die. And what is more, the wife of a potter or the child of a baker must also die. For everything that exists is subject to change, and nothing remains the same.

sections.title: Book VII: Eternity and Perspective
sections.content: Consider the whole universe as one living being, having one substance and one soul; and observe how all things have reference to one perception, the perception of this one living being; and how all things act with one movement; and how all things are the cooperating causes of all things that exist; observe too the continuous spinning of the thread and the structure of the web. Thou art a part of this great being, and a part of thee is separated; but thou hast a share in the government of the whole, and thou knowest it.

sections.title: Book VIII: Social Duty
sections.content: Constantly regard the universe as one living being, having one substance and one soul; and observe how all things trace back to one perception, the perception of this one living being; and how all things act with one movement; and how all things are the cooperating causes of all things which exist. Observe too the continuous spinning of the thread and the contexture of the web. Man is a part of this great being, and has his share in the government of the whole; but he is also separated from it, and knows what he does.

sections.title: Book IX: Human Nature
sections.content: It is in our power to have no opinion about a thing, and not to be disturbed in our soul; for things themselves have no natural power to form our judgments. Practice then from the start to say to every harsh appearance, 'Thou art but an appearance, and not absolutely the thing thou appearest to be.' And then examine it by those rules which thou hast, and first, and chiefly, by this: whether it concerns the things which are in our power, or things which are not in our power; and, if it concerns anything not in our power, be prepared to say that it is nothing to thee.

sections.title: Book X: Morning Renewal
sections.content: My soul, why dost thou not use thy freedom? For all that thou hast is sufficient for thee. Thou hast the power to will and not to will, and to choose and to refuse. Why then dost thou not use this power? If thou dost not use it, thou art enslaved. But if thou dost use it, thou art free. Remember that thou hast the power to withdraw thyself from many things, and to have need of few things. For thou hast the power to live as a philosopher, if thou dost not live as one, thou art not worthy of the name.

sections.title: Book XI: Divine Reason
sections.content: Everything that happens is in accordance with the nature of the universe. Nothing happens contrary to nature. If thou dost not see this, thou dost not see that all things happen for the best. For if thou dost see it, thou wilt be content with everything that happens. But if thou dost not see it, thou wilt be discontented with everything. Remember that the universe is one living being, having one substance and one soul. And remember that thou art a part of this great being, and hast thy share in the government of the whole.

sections.title: Book XII: Evening Reflection
sections.content: When thou art offended at any man's fault, immediately turn to thyself and reflect in what manner thou dost err thyself. For example, if thou art offended because a man is ungrateful, turn thy thoughts to thyself, and consider whether thou thyself hast not been ungrateful to others. If thou art offended because a man is faithless, consider whether thou thyself hast not been faithless. For by attending to this, thou wilt forget thy anger, and wilt be less prone to it in the future. Remember that to be offended is to be angry with thyself for not having foreseen the fault.

sections.title: The Allegory of the Cave
sections.content: Imagine human beings living in an underground cave, which has a mouth open towards the light and reaching all along the cave. Here they have been from their childhood, and have their legs and necks chained so that they cannot move, and can only see before them, being prevented by the chains from turning their heads. Above and behind them a fire is blazing at a distance, and between the fire and the prisoners there is a raised way; and you will see, if you look, a low wall built along the way, like the screen which puppet players have in front of them, over which they show the puppets. And do you see men passing along the wall carrying all sorts of vessels, and statues and figures of animals made of wood and stone and various materials, which appear over the wall? To them, the truth would be literally nothing but the shadows of the images. And now look again, and see what will naturally follow if the prisoners are released and disabused of their error. At first, when any of them is liberated and compelled suddenly to stand up and turn his neck around and walk and look towards the light, he will suffer sharp pains; the glare will distress him, and he will be unable to see the realities of which in his former state he had seen the shadows.

sections.title: The Theory of Forms
sections.content: We acknowledge that there exist both a beautiful that is absolute and a good that is absolute, and so on for all the things that we then set down as many. Now again we refer to them as belonging to a single Form of each as though the Form were a single thing, and we address it as 'that which is.' The many beautiful things and the rest which we previously described as many, we now describe conversely in accordance with a single Form, assuming it to be a single entity, and we call each of them 'what really is.' We say that the many beautiful things are the objects of sight but not of intelligence, while the Forms are the objects of intelligence but not of sight. Then what is that which sees? The eye, I suppose. And does not that which hears hear by means of the ear? By all means. But the eye cannot see itself; and similarly, that which knows has a knowable Form of knowledge. But the Good itself is not sight, nor is it knowledge, but it is the cause of both—something still more honorable than these.

sections.title: Justice in the Soul
sections.content: Justice is produced in the soul when each part does its own work and does not meddle with what is not its own. The rational part ought to rule, being wise and exercising forethought on behalf of the whole soul; the spirited part ought to be its ally and supporter; and these two, thus nurtured and educated, should preside over the appetitive part, which comprises the greater bulk of each person's soul and is by nature most insatiable for wealth. They must watch over it, lest it become filled with the so-called pleasures of the body and, growing great and strong, no longer do its own work but attempt to enslave and rule over those which it is not fitted by kind to rule, thus overturning the whole life of all. And so the rational and spirited parts, when they have learned their own work and been educated in it, will preside over the appetitive part and keep watch, lest by being filled and saturated with the pleasures of the body, it becomes great and strong and no longer minds its own business.

sections.title: The Philosopher King
sections.content: Until philosophers rule as kings or those who are now called kings and leading men genuinely and adequately philosophize, that is, until political power and philosophy entirely coincide, while the many natures who at present pursue either one exclusively are forcibly prevented from doing so, cities will have no rest from evils, nor, I think, will the human race. And, until this happens, the constitution we've been describing in theory will never be born to the fullest extent possible or see the light of the sun. It is because I saw how very paradoxical this statement would be that I hesitated to make it for so long. For it is hard to face up to the fact that there can be no happiness, either public or private, in any other city. The true captain must pay attention to the seasons of the year, the sky, the stars, the winds, and all that pertains to his craft if he is to be a true ruler of a ship. So too must the philosopher-ruler understand the Forms and be able to guide the city accordingly.

sections.title: The Ladder of Love
sections.content: The true order of going, or being led by another, to the things of love, is to begin from the beauties of earth and mount upwards for the sake of that other beauty, using these steps only, and from one going on to two, and from two to all fair forms; and from fair forms to fair practices, and from fair practices to fair notions, until from fair notions he arrives at the notion of absolute beauty, and at last knows what the essence of beauty is. This, my dear Socrates, is that life above all others which man should live, in the contemplation of beauty absolute; a beauty which if you once beheld, you would see not to be after the measure of gold, and garments, and fair boys and youths, whose presence now entrances you. And you and many a one would be content to live seeing them only and conversing with them without meat or drink, if that were possible—you only want to look at them and to be with them. But what if man had eyes to see the true beauty—the divine beauty, I mean, pure and clear and unalloyed, not clogged with the pollutions of mortality and all the colors and vanities of human life?

sections.title: Diotima's Teaching
sections.content: Love is not a god but is rather a spirit that mediates between the human and divine realms. Love is wanting to possess the good forever. This is why all people who love seek to be creative both physically and spiritually, for creation is our drive toward immortality. Those who are pregnant in body are drawn more to women and pursue love in that way, seeking to provide themselves with immortality, remembrance, and happiness through having children. But those who are pregnant in soul—for there are some whose souls are more pregnant than their bodies—conceive that which is proper for a soul to conceive and bring forth: wisdom and all other virtue. The greatest and fairest sort of wisdom is that which is concerned with the ordering of cities and households, and that is called moderation and justice. When such a one from his youth has his soul pregnant with these virtues, and being arrived at manhood desires to beget and bring forth, he goes about seeking beauty in which he may beget—for he will never beget in deformity.

sections.title: The Unexamined Life
sections.content: The unexamined life is not worth living for a human being. For if I tell you that this would be disobedience to the god, and that therefore I cannot be silent, you will not believe me on the grounds that I am being ironic. And if I say again that the greatest good for a human being is to engage in daily discussion about virtue and the other things you hear me talking about, examining both myself and others—and that a life without this sort of examination is not worth living for a human being—you will believe me even less. This is how things are, gentlemen, though it is not easy to convince you. I am not accustomed to thinking that I deserve anything bad. If I had money, I would propose a fine of as much as I could pay, since that would not harm me at all. But as things stand, I cannot pay, unless you want to fix my fine at the sum I could afford. Perhaps I could pay you a mina of silver. So I propose a fine of that amount.

sections.title: The Socratic Mission
sections.content: I go about doing nothing else than urging you, young and old, not to care for your bodies or for money more than for the perfection of your souls, or even so much; and I tell you that virtue does not come from money, but from virtue comes money and all other good things to man, both to the individual and to the state. If by saying these things I corrupt the youth, these things must be harmful. But if anyone asserts that I say other things than these, he says what is untrue. Therefore I would say, men of Athens, either be persuaded by Anytus or not, and either acquit me or not, knowing that I will not do otherwise even if I am to die many times over. You know, men of Athens, that the god stationed me here, as I think and believe, with orders to spend my life in philosophy, examining myself and others. To fear death is nothing other than to think oneself wise when one is not; for it is to think one knows what one does not know.

sections.title: Philosophy as Preparation for Death
sections.content: Those who practice philosophy in the right way are in training for dying and they fear death least of all people. Consider it thus: if they are altogether estranged from the body and desire to have their soul by itself alone, would it not be quite absurd for them to be afraid and resentful when this happens? Would they not willingly go to a place where, on arrival, they may hope to attain that for which they had yearned during their lifetime, that is, wisdom, and where they would be rid of the presence of that from which they are estranged? Many a man has been willing to go to the underworld, driven by the hope of seeing there an end of his love, or wife, or son, and conversing with them. Will then a true lover of wisdom, who has a firm grasp of this same hope and thinks that he will not find it to any extent except in Hades, be resentful of dying and not gladly undertake the journey thither?

sections.title: Recollection and Knowledge
sections.content: Learning is nothing other than recollection. According to this theory we must at some previous time have learned what we now recollect. This is only possible if our soul existed somewhere before it took on this human form. Thus the soul is likely to be immortal. We must have acquired our knowledge of all the realities before we were born, and if we have acquired it before birth and lost it at birth, but afterwards by the use of our senses in connection with those very realities we mentioned just now, we regained the knowledge which we had before, would not what we call learning be the recovery of our own knowledge? Should we not be right to call this recollection? Quite so. It was possible for the soul, when it perceived things either through sight or hearing or some other sense, to be reminded by these of other things which it had forgotten, things which were associated with them and which they resembled, whether like or unlike. As I say, one of two things is true: either we were born with this knowledge and all of us know these things throughout life, or those who later, we say, are learning are only recollecting.

sections.title: The Paradox of Inquiry
sections.content: How will you look for something when you don't in the least know what it is? How on earth are you going to set up something you don't know as the object of your search? To put it another way, even if you come right up against it, how will you know that what you have found is the thing you didn't know? I know what you want to say, Meno. Do you realize what a debater's argument you are bringing up, that a man cannot search either for what he knows or for what he does not know? He cannot search for what he knows—since he knows it, there is no need to search—nor for what he does not know, for he does not know what to look for. The soul, then, being immortal and having been born many times, and having seen all things both here and in the other world, has learned everything that is. So we need not be surprised if it can recall the knowledge of virtue or anything else which it once possessed. All nature is akin, and the soul has learned everything, so that when a man has recalled one thing only—a process men call learning—there is no reason why he should not find out all the rest, if he is brave and does not tire of the search.

sections.title: Introduction
sections.content: One is not born, but rather becomes, a woman. No biological, psychological, or economic fate determines the figure that the human female presents in society; it is civilization as a whole that produces this creature, intermediate between male and female, which is described as feminine. Only the intervention of someone else can establish an individual as an Other. The term 'feminine' is used symmetrically with 'masculine,' but the symmetry is false. The category of the feminine is presented as symmetrical, but in fact it is not.

sections.title: The Independent Woman
sections.content: To emancipate woman is to refuse to confine her to the relations she bears to man, not to deny them to her; let her have her independent existence and she will continue none the less to exist for him also: mutually recognizing each other as subject, each will yet remain for the other an other. The reciprocity of their relations will not do away with the miracles—desire, possession, love, dream, adventure—worked by the division of human beings into two separate categories; and far from being enmired in static materialism, woman will continue to make the part of the sky she inherits shine with stars and planets.

sections.title: The Ethics of Ambiguity
sections.content: To will oneself free is also to will others free. This will is not an abstract formula. It points out to each person concrete action to be achieved here and now. In the light of this idea, the world appears as a field of infinite possibilities, and man must decide for himself what he is going to be. But this decision is not made once and for all; it is made anew at every moment. Freedom is not given to man: he must conquer it. And this conquest is never finished; it is a perpetual struggle against the forces that threaten to engulf him.

sections.title: The Body
sections.content: The body is not a thing, it is a situation: it is our grasp on the world and a sketch of our projects. The body is not perceived as a pure object, but as a situation through which we live the world. The lived body is not the body as seen by the anatomist or the physiologist; it is the body as experienced in its relation to the world. The body is the instrument of our grasp on the world, and this grasp is always situated. The body is not a fortress, but a vehicle; it is not a prison, but a means of communication with the world.

sections.title: Authenticity
sections.content: To be authentic is to refuse to let oneself be defined by others, to refuse the roles that society assigns to us. Authenticity demands that we assume our freedom, that we take responsibility for our choices. But this authenticity is not a state that we achieve once and for all; it is a perpetual task. We must constantly question the values that are imposed on us, the roles that are assigned to us. We must constantly create ourselves anew. Authenticity is not conformity to a pre-existing model, but the creation of oneself through one's choices.
